thread.title: Bills’ McCoy, Watkins sit out vs. Giants
thread.title_full: Bills’ McCoy, Watkins sit out vs. Giants | Boston Herald

author: Herald Staff
title: Bills’ McCoy, Watkins sit out vs. Giants
text:
Buffalo Bills coach Rex Ryan ruled out running back LeSean McCoy and receiver Sammy Watkins from playing against the New York Giants on Sunday.
Ryan initially said he’d never use the word “out” after the two players missed their second straight day of practice yesterday. Then, he shook his head and said reporters could figure it out on their own.
McCoy is sitting out to rest a left hamstring injury that’s nagged him since he was hurt Aug. 18. Watkins was sidelined after hurting his right calf in a win at Miami on Sunday.
For the Giants, the return of wide receiver Victor Cruz is on hold. Coach Tom Coughlin said Cruz will not play after aggravating a calf injury. Instead, Cruz will work with trainers.
There is no timetable for Cruz’ return.
“Victor tried it, and it did not feel right to him so he did not practice,” Coughlin said.
Cruz hurt his calf in training camp in August and has not practiced with the team. He has not played in an NFL game since his season-ending knee injury last Oct. 12 against the Eagles.
Luck shouldering pain
Indianapolis Colts quarterback Andrew Luck was listed as a limited participant in practice for the second straight day with a sore right shoulder.
Luck is listed as questionable but is still expected to start Sunday against Jacksonville.
Luck was restricted to handing the ball off and pitching it to running backs during the portion of practice the media was able to watch. He also spent time at the indoor practice facility while the rest of the team was stretching and during the special teams part of practice.
Luck injured his shoulder in the Colts’ 35-33 win over the Tennessee Titans last weekend.
Luck and coach Chuck Pagano does not usually speak to reporters after practices, and offensive coordinator Pep Hamilton deferred all comments about injuries to Pagano.
Backup quarterback Matt Hasselbeck ’s workload was about the same as Wednesday, when Luck took a rare day off. Hasselbeck said he was certain Luck would play. Luck was injured in last weekend’s 35-33 at Tennessee.
The fourth-year quarterback has never missed a start since Indy (1-2) took him with the first pick of the 2012 draft.  . . .
The Chicago Bears hope to get quarterback Jay Cutler back for Sunday’s game against the Oakland Raiders and are preparing to go with Jimmy Clausen again if he is not ready.
Cutler practiced on a limited basis for the second consecutive day after sitting out last week’s 26-0 loss at Seattle because of a pulled hamstring.
He responded “we’ll see” when asked if he will play against the Raiders.
Jets’ Decker hopeful
The New York Jets are hoping to have Eric Decker back in the lineup in London on Sunday. The star wide receiver participated in some team drills for the first time since spraining his left knee nearly two weeks ago.
Decker sat out last Sunday against Philadelphia. His status remained uncertain for the Jets’ game against the Miami Dolphins on Sunday in London.
Cornerback Darrelle Revis was limited for the second straight day with a sore hamstring, and running back Chris Ivory was a full participant after being limited with a strained quadriceps that kept him on the sideline against the Eagles.
Tight end Jeff Cumberland (concussion), guard Willie Colon (sprained MCL) and receiver Chris Owusu (knee) are out. . . .
Ravens rookie wide receiver Breshad Perriman will be sidelined indefinitely after he had arthroscopic surgery this week to repair a torn posterior cruciate ligament in his right knee. . . .
The Denver Broncos agreed to a one-year deal with veteran offensive tackle Tyler Polumbus , 30, and released safety Josh Bush .
Mariota gains honor
Titans quarterback Marcus Mariota and Bills cornerback Ronald Darby are the NFL’s rookies of the month for September.
Mariota, the No. 2 pick overall out of Oregon, led all rookies with 833 yards passing, eight touchdowns and a passer rating of 109.2 He tied Mark Rypien for the most TDs by any player in his first three NFL games.
Darby, a second-round pick out of Florida State, is tied for the NFL lead with two interceptions. He also led all players with eight passes defensed.
Broncos linebacker DeMarcus Ware won his first Defensive Player of the Month honor in his 11-year career, helping the No. 1-ranked defense with 3.5 sacks.
